claim: Alexander Acosta met with Epstein's lawyers in March 2008 to negotiate the non-prosecution agreement.
Jeffrey Epstein owned a property at 9 East 71st Street in Manhattan used as his primary New York residence.
Epstein traveled between Palm Beach and New York on his private aircraft (N908JE) on multiple occasions in 2005.
The non-prosecution agreement was finalized in September 2007, shielding Epstein and his co-conspirators from federal prosecution.
Epstein's Palm Beach home at 358 El Brillo Way was the primary location of criminal activity documented in the FBI investigation.
Southern Trust Company was a shell entity controlled by Epstein used to funnel payments.
Epstein's aircraft logs show flights to Little Saint James between 2001 and 2006.
The FBI's investigation identified at least 36 underage victims in the Palm Beach case.
Epstein held accounts at Deutsche Bank that were flagged in suspicious activity reports.
Communications between Epstein and co-conspirators show awareness of the ongoing FBI investigation in 2006.
Epstein's contact books included entries for multiple government officials and foreign dignitaries.
DOJ prosecutors in the Southern District of Florida received communications from Epstein's legal team between 2006 and 2007.
Epstein's New Mexico ranch (Zorro Ranch) was referenced in correspondence related to victim recruitment.
The 2008 NPA included a co-conspirator provision that prevented prosecution of named associates.
Epstein registered as a sex offender in Florida in 2009 following his release from Palm Beach County jail.
FBI 302 interview reports document victim statements collected between 2005 and 2007.
Epstein's estate planning documents reference multiple offshore accounts and trusts.
Surveillance records show Epstein at his Manhattan townhouse in the months prior to his 2019 arrest.
Epstein's private plane made multiple transatlantic flights to Paris between 2000 and 2010.
Documents show payments from Epstein entities to individuals matching names of known victims.
The SDFL prosecution team exchanged multiple drafts of the NPA with Epstein's attorneys via email.
Epstein's property at Little Saint James (USVI) was purchased in 1998 through a shell company.
Phone records show contact between Epstein and at least two sitting senators in 2004.
Epstein's 2009 plea deal work release program was approved despite objections from federal prosecutors.
Internal FBI memos from 2007 indicate senior officials were briefed on the Epstein investigation status.
Epstein wired funds to an associate in France weeks before the NPA was signed.
The Palm Beach Police Department opened its investigation of Epstein in March 2005 based on a tip.
Epstein employed a network of recruiters who were paid cash for identifying potential victims.
Evidence of tampering with witness testimony was documented in internal prosecution notes.
Epstein's known associates include individuals who later held senior positions in financial institutions.
The 2019 indictment cited crimes occurring between 2002 and 2005 based on new victim testimony.
Victim impact statements were filed with the court in 2019 detailing abuse at multiple Epstein properties.
Epstein's Rolodex contained over 500 entries; many high-profile names appeared multiple times.
Correspondence between Epstein's New York and Palm Beach offices referenced ongoing victim recruitment in 2004.
The DOJ Office of Professional Responsibility investigated the handling of the 2008 NPA in 2018.
Epstein paid legal fees for co-conspirators who were interviewed by the FBI.
Multiple wire transfers from Epstein accounts totaling over $1 million were made in 2007 to individuals later identified as associates.
Epstein's New York property was searched by the FBI in July 2019, yielding evidence including photographs.
Epstein-connected shell companies appear in Panama Papers records.
Communications obtained via FOIA show DOJ Main Justice was briefed on the Epstein plea before it was finalized.
Epstein's estate was valued at over $500 million at the time of his 2019 arrest.
The NPA required Epstein to pay restitution to victims but the amount was not made public.
Records show Epstein donated to academic institutions as part of a reputational rehabilitation campaign.
Victim advocacy groups were excluded from NPA negotiations in violation of the CVRA.
Epstein's personal calendars show meetings with co-conspirators at his townhouse during the SDFL investigation period.
Financial records indicate Epstein provided gifts and payments to at least 10 individuals connected to his criminal enterprise.
A 2006 FBI threat assessment classified Epstein as a high-risk sex offender.
Documents show Epstein's legal team submitted a 56-page memorandum opposing federal charges in 2007.
Epstein's victim recruitment network was described as multi-tiered in FBI investigative reports.
The SDFL office declined FBI recommendations to seek additional charges beyond the Palm Beach counts.
